headline: Veggie Pot Pie
description: This pot pie is vegetarian. Potatoes, mushrooms, cauliflower, green beans, and carrots are cooked in a savory sauce, then baked a flaky pie crust.

video.description: Flavorful vegetables in a flaky crust make a perfect pot pie!
video.name: Veggie Pot Pie

name: Veggie Pot Pie
recipeIngredient: 1 cup fresh green beans, trimmed and snapped into 1/2 inch pieces
1 (14.1 ounce) package double-crust pie pastry, thawed

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Heat oil in a large skillet or saucepan. Add mushrooms, onions, and garlic; cook for 3 to 5 minutes, stirring frequently. Stir in carrots, potatoes, and celery. Stir in cauliflower and green beans; add vegetable broth and bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer until vegetables are just tender, about 5 minutes. Season with salt and pepper.
Mix water, cornstarch, and soy sauce in a small bowl until cornstarch is completely dissolved; stir into vegetables and cook until sauce thickens, about 3 minutes.
Roll out 1/2 of the dough to line an 11x7-inch baking dish. Pour vegetable filling into the pastry-lined dish. Roll out remaining dough; arrange over filling, then seal and flute the edges.
Bake in preheated oven until pie is golden brown on top, about 30 minutes.

review.reviewBody: The ingredients made 2 pies.

This is a great recipe! My family loved it! I will put a little less vegetable broth next time, though. I didn't have cauliflower, so I added broccoli and some asparagus. Also added about 1 tablespoon of tarragon. Delicious!
Terrible. I followed the recipe exactly, and it was soup. Flour instead of cornstarch and lots of it or way less broth.

This was really good and easy to make. I only used a top pie crust which is plenty of crust for me. I replaced the carrot with butternut squash because that's what I needed to use up, and it worked great. I agree with others to cut down on the amount of pepper. Adding the soy sauce makes it flavorful but I think next time I'm going to try Worcestershire. Just two of us so got to enjoy leftovers!
Great and easy meal to make.

Just made this for supper. Will definitely make again. Made a few changes to fit what was in my fridge and pantry: had only one potato, and thought it enough; used flour (about 1/3 c) instead of cornstarch to thicken; used refrigerated piecrust (top only); added frozen peas (about 1 c); added a tbsp butter with less oil to saute onions and mushrooms; used combo chicken and vegetable broth (needed to use up the chicken broth!). I was ready to pour the cooked veggies into the pie plate and saw the cauliflower still sitting on the counter. I blanched it for a couple of minutes and added it in - no prob. I also blanched the carrots, celery and potatoes in the beginning. Very good!
Yummy!!!!!
I was shocked by the deep flavors..so little spice or herbs..yet delicious. I think the soy adds the depth as the mushrooms..mushrooms. !
So good! New house favorite
This was amazing. The whole family loved it and didn't miss the meat!
Cut the amount of broth in half and cut the amount of pepper in half
I thought it was ok but I was the only one. The pepper made it way too spicy for the rest of the family. Texture was ok with 4tbsp of corn starch but it was still very runny.

Really delicious.
I thought 3 cups stock was too much, and I reduced that to 2 cups. Even then, I needed to add 1 TBSP more cornstarch to get the sauce thick enough not to be soup. 
I used puff pastry for top and bottom crusts - delicious!
My favorite for sure! Tasty, filling and a fabulous comfort food for this new vegetarian. But a sure winner for carnivores too!
Needed a recipe for a vegan friend and we all loved it! Made more veggies than fit in the pie, but that’s okay would definitely recommend.

I never review recipes but this deserves one. I’ve made this twice now, once following the recipe almost exactly (a little less broth) and once putting cheese in and whatever veggies I had on hand. Both times, my family gobbled it up. 

My carnivorous husband said it’s the best veggie dish he’s had. My very picky son ate his whole plate. I could personally eat this every day. So good, warm, filling and comforting. Thanks for a fabulous recipe.
The kids gobbled it up! We used a bit more cornstarch than the recipe stated to thicken it a bit more. We will make this again!
This pie is LIFE! 11/10 will be making again!
I strongly recommend beating an egg or two and mixing it in with the veggies to keep the filling from falling apart.

DELICIOUS!!! Thanks for the recipe and comments.
Aside from one or two veggies I had to substitute for what was in my fridge and adding 4-tablespoons of corn starch all the ingredients were the same.I used a veggie paste I bought at Costco — Better Than Bullion It’s already spiced so nothing else to add and it’s much cheaper, better flavour, and smaller to store. Yes, it took a long time chopping and dicing but since I didn’t measure the veggies I had enough for at least another pie or on rice or to freeze.
The ratios in the recipe don't work out--we had at least two cups of filling left over, and we were filling an extra large casserole dish.

My whole family loved this pie. I cooked the vegetables longer than the recipe said and added an extra tablespoon of cornstarch to thicken the sauce. I was surprised my kids ate all the veggies without complaining. I will make this again.

My first pot pie, and it was great positive reinforcement! Absolutely delicious, not as cumbersome or time consuming as I anticipated, and... YUM. I had many of the veggies in the recipe on hand: onions, garlic, potato, cauliflower (purple), carrots; didn't have mushrooms, celery, or green beans, but added some peas from the freezer. With just the soy sauce, salt/pepper, and veggie broth, this was rich with flavor and filling. All four family members loved it, including 2 teenagers. Will definitely be a regular for us.
Great recipe! I did double the corn starch and that worked well. The family loved it!

I made this with alterations from reviews. In addition to the sauce in the recipe, I added one can of cream of mushroom soup and 1.5 cans of broth to veggies (potatoes, broccoli, cauliflower, carrots, celery - which I cooked until soft) instead of the 3 cups of broth (I also used broth in the sauce instead of water and increased cornstarch to 4 tablespoons). I added some great all purpose seasoning mix ("Seasoning for All the Things from Imperfect Foods) and baked it in a cast iron skillet. Was using a pie crust mix I've never used before (mistake). I opted to do a crumble style top crust out of convenience and it was so good! I had leftover filling and made another one today. So good! the crumble crust means every bite has a bit of crunchy crust. I give 4 stars bc I altered the recipe. I am certain the original recipe is far too runny.
I didn't have soy sauce. Added plain water instead of vegetable broth. The filling was too good . Just too yumm.. easy dinner ready...

I always precook crust for 12 minutes with foil around the edges. I cooked 3/4 cup of white long grain rice toasted in sesame seed oil. Used broccoli, sugar snap, green beans, carrots, celery, water chrnuts, onions an red pepper for veggies. Used potato starch and vegetable stock with soy, Hawaii chili water, and a touch of Tia chili for the liquid. It took 45 minutes at 350 for the top to get done. I loved it, and so did the family.
What can I use in place of soy sauce?

Easy and tasty. I followed the recipe with one exception. I only used a top crust and baked in Emile Henry pie dish. I feel like you could mess with the types of veggies and it would still come out great.

Tastes great! Beware though, when I made it, there was enough filling for 3 pies. I ended up making two pies with no top crusts, as I only had 2 crusts. I will probably eat the rest of it over rice. Other than that, very easy to make!

Added some veggie ground round. Was worried it would be too 'soupy' to cut and serve, so doubled the corn starch. Might have been too much Corn Starch. But it held together ok - ish. Always hard to cut and serve a pot pie. Found that cutting cold (2nd night) was easier, and then heated it in the microwave. Still, individual pies would be better if you want to avoid the slop.
This was so good! I didn’t have cornstarch so I used flour (doubled the amount of tablespoons), and it worked great. Would make again
Hands down, the best veggie pot pie -- ever!

The flavor was wonderful but the sauce was way to runny! Next time I will thicken it with flour instead (about 1/3 cup or even a little more). I have made many chicken pot pies over the years and the helps the crust not get soggy like it does if you fallow the recipe.

Even though I wasn't so sure about the recipe, I trusted the reviews and made it anyway. It turned out to by really really good!
P.S. I used leek instead of celery and cauliflower.
Also the amount turned out to be enough for two pies, so I'll only be using half the quantities mentioned from the next time.

Great comfort food option! I took the advice of the reviews and prebaked my bottom crust and not using all the liquid. I used a regular pie pan so I have enough filling in the freezer now for a second pie.
Delicious flavours and perfect texture. I added triple the recommended amount of cornstarch and it was still a bit runny.

Vegetarian daughter loves. I have to admit I shortcut this recipe in the interest of time. I use Pillsbury ready crust and frozen cauliflower, carrots, green beans, corn (whatever veggies you prefer). I just sautéed the fresh veggies first and mixed in partially thawed frozen veggies into the broth to heat through. Make sure to cut your potatoes into small chunks so they cook well. A little extra corn starch is needed to make the filling less runny. I was able to prep the filling the night before and then toss in the ready made crust the following night after work. We freeze the leftovers in individual pieces for quick college girl meals.

I followed the recipe exactly and the flavor was great! I used an easy homemade shortening pie crust for the bottom and top; it was light and flaky and complimented the filling well. However I will agree that the filling was a bit runny, I served it kind of “deconstructed” - I’m not sure if you could double the cornstarch or something, I tried to add some more in before I poured it into the pan but it got a little clumpy. So flavor = awesome but if you’re trying to impress your guests with presentation I would either play with the consistency to thicken it up or maybe make individual servings in ramekins. Will make again!
I've made it before and I'll make it again. It is incredibly delicious! It makes a lot.
I forgot to havbe a covering but other than that, pretty good.
Whole family loved it including my 3 year old and 1 year old!

Delicous! The prep time is long, but well worth it. I agree with the review that suggested doubling the recipe and freezing half for a second pie later. I set my oven at 400 instead of 425, because it is a smaller oven. even after starting at a lower temp, my crust was browned after about 15 min. I suggest to keep watch over yours, because cooking times may vary. I will definitely make again.

If one needs to major changes, then it should not have a "major" rating. It needs herbs like sage, thyme, rosemary, bay leaf and marjoram. It also needs nutritional yeast to make it taste cheesy. I like to use soy sauce instead of salt.
For what it is, it was great. It just seemed a little unfulfilling? Like it can't live up to chicken or beef pop pies.

I made changes due to other reviews and what vegetables I had on hand... I came out great really... even using frozen Pillsbury ready made dough and frozen veggies!
Definitely had a LOT of filling left over to make more pies!
My daughter I loved it! I omitted cauliflower and added roasted acorn squash.

I doubled the amount of cornstarch as suggested by some reviewers. Very tasty and the vegetables were tender but not mushy. I'm considering trying some fried tofu cubes in it the next time that I make it. I used Better than Bouillon vegetable base for the broth and the seasoning was just right.

So good. Used red potatoes and added fresh green beans and brussel sprouts and brushed the top with melted butter before baking. Also added the suggested extra tbsp cornstarch. It takes two of the ready-made crusts. Today is the third time I have made it. Popular with everyone!
Turned out great, big hit with my picky 14 year old daughter!

Delicious and warm comfort food. I love to add extra cheese and fennel seeds.
Try it. MG

This was clearly a 5-star for me. I added more cornstarch, used 2 pillsbury pie crusts on the bottom and pre cooked - then finished recipe with one crust on top (suggested by another reviewer). Didn't change anything else.
This is awesome!

So fantastic! I added an extra tablespoon of cornstarch after reading other reviews that it’s too runny. Also, I put the bottom crust in the oven for a few minutes before adding the filling and top crust so it wouldn’t be too soggy. I used a slotted spoon to fill the pie to omit extra liquid.

Amazing! I'm not a fan of soy sauce and tend to underseason everything. I was a bit wary if the recipe but followed it almost precisely. Added some spinach I needed to use up.

Result is one of the best things I've made. The soy sauce is there but plays very well with everything else. This is a superb recipe! Very easy.

Don't have time for pie crusts? Make this as a stew. But it's so much better with a flaky and buttery crust wow.

This was amazingly good. I added 2 dashes of nutmeg, thyme, and cheyenne. For some reason mine didn't turn out liquidy like some people are saying. I used all the same veggies only used just a tad more of everything so more water might have gotten soaked up and i added about a cup or more of frozen peas. I also cooked the bottom crust at 400 for about 10 minutes and popped the bubbles every 5 minutes. After filling it i put the top crust on and cooked it at 400 for 20-30minutes i let it sit until it thickened more. This is my new favorite recipe

My son devoured this, even though it's vegetarian! I had two issues - the sauce didn't thicken and the bottom crust ended up soggy, maybe because the sauce was too watery. I am reading the reviews now that say to add extra corn starch, so next time I will try that. I will also bake the bottom crust for a little while before adding the veggies and putting the top crust on, to make sure it gets cooked. This is definitely something I will make again.

Recipe was great, will make again! I substituted for the cauliflower, and added peas. After reading other reviews, i reduced the veg broth to 2.5 cups, rather than three, and used 4 tbs of cornstarch. Was the perfect consistency in my opinion. If i hadn't modified, it would have been way too runny. Also, i read a recipe on Food Network that said to use puff pastry, which i did, and it was awesome. Would recommend, nice and fluffy and crisp.

I was incredulous while working on this because it was so liquidy, added an extra tbsp as advised and it was dang awesome! Added sage, thyme and made the crust with fresh rosemary blended in, so good!
So good! My mom and bf loved it! Make sure to use 3-4 tablespoons cornstarch.

Amazing!! My ingredients: 2 containers of crescent roll dough, 2 TBSP extra virgin olive oil, 5 TBSP minced garlic, 3/4 chopped onion, 2 cups chopped baby portobello mushrooms. 3 carrots, 3 stalks celery, 1 potato, 2 cups chopped cauliflower, 1/2 cup corn, 1 can creamed corn. 2 TBSP corn starch, 2 TBSP soy sauce, water. 1 packet chicken broth in 2 cups water. Salt, pepper, herbs de provence, 1 TBSP fresh rosemary. Bake at 350 degrees with 1 layer of crescent rolls and filling then add additional layer of crescent rolls on top and bake additional 10-15 minutes.
I used 2 teaspoons kosher salt, Pillsbury pie dough, and four tablespoons of corn starch like the reviews said. This was delicious and my husband LOVED it.

It's a great vegetable medley! I used 2 cans of campbells cream of mushroom instead of making a sauce (i sauteed the carrot, onion and celery, boiled potato, cauliflower and green beans) mixed it with the soup and no soggy bottom! I also added about a cup of shredded cheddar, used store bought pie crusts. It was great! 10/10 would bake again

This was delicious! My family loved it and my nine year old twins had two servings. They even asked if I'd pack it for their lunch tomorrow! I did use 4 tbsp. of corn starch as others recommended. Also subbed asparagus for green beans and sweet potatoes for white. I will definitely make this again.

Savory and delicious. I added one teaspoon of herbes de Provence, an herb mixture I love and use often, with the vegetables. I made individual pies for a gathering, and topped each with puff pastry (cut into squares) instead of using pie crust on the top and bottom. This recipe made 6 5-inch individual pies. Will definitely make again. Perfect meal to enjoy heading into the fall/winter.

I have made this veggie pot pie several times now., and I think it is excellent. I made it exactly as written the first time, and it came out perfectly. But the great thing about this recipe is that you can easily change up the veggies to use what you have on hand. The seasonings are pretty much perfect as is, IMO, but I have also tried subbing worcestershire sauce for the soy sauce and adding thyme to give it more of a "fall" taste, and it was really, really good. I always make my pies with an all-butter homemade crust, because that is what I like. But you can easily use any kind of crust, even a store-bought, and this recipe will still taste great!

This is an excellent recipe! I used store bought crust - I know how my crust turns out (eh) - and I would suggest buying an extra crust. It took three rounds of frozen crust for me. My fiance ate it all up! He kept going back for more - and he's usually a finicky eater!

I was looking for a dairy free entree and found this Veggie Pot Pie recipe. The only changes I made were to leave out the garlic and use four tablespoons of cornstarch as suggested by other reviewers who found the consistency too thin. Extending the cooking time for thickening from 3 minutes to 6 or 7 and cooling the pie for one half hour before eating, produced a very nice result. My husband and I loved the flavor and we will add it to our favorites list. I am planning to freeze half of the pie for the future.
Made it twice now and loved it but still having trouble getting the 'gravy' thick enough.
Too thin/soupy and too peppery. This is spicy. I used finely ground pepper and I think I should've used very coarse pepper.

I have to say first of all that I have never tasted this pie exactly as the recipe is made, but I love it! I didn't have any issue with the thickness of the sauce, and after a disaster with store bought puff pastry the first time I tried to make this, I tried to make the recommended pie crust and had a much better time with that. 
I didn't use mushrooms, cauliflower, or green beans. Instead I added parsnips (3) and a small amount of sweet potato. 
I also added sage to the seasoning, and changed the veggie broth to 2 cups broth and 1 cup white wine. 
I followed the pie crust exactly and then pre-cooked it for about 10 minutes as the first time the pie was soggy. 
Overall this is a great recipe that is easy to play around with...and best of all my meat loving boyfriend says it has flavour!
Awesome!! My son finished more than half the pie himself! I added some more seasoning to give it a little kick!

I LOVED THIS! Talk about comfort food! This was amazing! I made a couple changes...I used 4 cups of vegetable broth - I ised better than boullion vegetable broth - it's well worth it! I also used frozen mixed veg instead of green beans because I didn't have any. I also used flour not cornstarch and I added some freeze dried basil and thyme. This was amazing as a "pie" but I had tons of filling left so am eating it as a stew. YUM! Oh! I also used tender flake pie shells for less fuss! THANK YOU FOR THIS AWESOME RECIPE!

May have cooked things a bit more than suggested...but otherwise pretty much made it as directed. I did bake the bottom crust about 12 minutes before adding the veggies. I have made this dish twice now and definitely will make again.
So delicious! (And I don't even like pot pie!!) wish it had been more of a gravy consistency than soup, but I'll try a little more cornstarch next time!

I omit the black pepper and the mushrooms due to our family's preferences, but otherwise this is a wonderful recipe. It's a lot of work, so I don't make it very often, but when I do it's pure comfort food.

I made this into 6 individual sized pies, and they turned out wonderfully! It was just the right amount of filling for the 6 small pot pie pans, and I used the Crust for Veggie Pot pie recipe also on this site. I baked them in the oven until they were finished all the way, and then froze and individually vacuum sealed each pie. Since the hubby refuses to eat veggies, I'm the only one who will enjoy these, so I take out one at a time to defrost in the fridge and reheat in the oven. They are SO delicious, and such a perfect meal for a cool Autumn or Winter day.

I wouldn't classify this as an easy recipe, by any means. Mainly due to the labor of the crusts, and assembling all of the little pies. But they are so worth the effort to have the meal already put together, and just needing to be heated up. I doubled the recipe for crust, to have enough for both the bottom and top full crusts for the pies.

I am not sure how just assembling and then immediately freezing (without baking first) them would have turned out in comparison to what I did, but I would guess that you could just freeze the uncooked version to bake all the way later. It may take more time in the oven at that point, though, and by the time I put one of these little pies in the oven, I am not prepared to wait very long until I can eat it! 

 I did personalize the ingredients for my own tastes, and for what I had on hand, and put some "No-chicken" broth powder into making the crust, which I HIGHLY recommend, since it

I really wanted this to work! I followed the recipe exactly except added two tbs more corn starch as other reviewers suggested...and it was still WAY too runny! It was more like eating vegetable soup with crust :-(. Still tasty, but not at all what I was hoping for. Not sure what I did wrong, but will search for another recipe!
I didn't have all the veggies, so I just substituted what I did have and it was still delicious!

I love chicken pot pie, but don't eat much meat. This is fantastic. I put it in a casserole dish with "old fashioned flaky pie crust" from this site on the top only. Next time I'll experiment with other veggies...I'm sure different combinations will be just as good!

I love this recipe! I halved the recipes but used the same amount of cornstarch and used Pillsbury pre-made pie crusts in a pie dish. I baked the bottom one first 10 minutes. I used frozen cauliflower, beans and carrots, canned mushrooms and fresh ingredients otherwise. It was so so so good, the next day it was even better!!

We've made this recipe for years. I can't seem to get back into my All Recipes account, but I signed up again to find this recipe just to save it here. Thank goodness I saved it in my files because the poor old recipe is getting pretty tattered. The recipe is wonderful and actually makes two pies for us. We always freeze them, unbaked, and when the kids come they ask for it. We make a big salad to serve with it. This is a wonderful recipe for any vegetarian or foodie type. It's warm and satisfying and just plain yummy. Thank you for a wonderful go to veggie/non veggie recipe. P.S we use ready made pie crust like Pillsbury, just to make it easier.
I follow the recipe exactly as it was and my husband (a meat eater) loved it! So did I! Best vegetarian dish I have ever had.
Beef broth was used instead of vegetable broth and it turned out great!
This recipe was amazing. I substituted sweet potatoes for the regular potatoes. I will definitely be making this again soon. Perfect for cold weather days.
Delicious!!!!! I used broccoli instead of cauliflower and I should've used more cornstarch to thicken sauce because my pie just fell apart so it was more like a stew.. Still delicious!

This works well as written, and can serve as a starting point for variations, depending on available vegetables, the wish (or not) to add a mock-meat of some kind, the wish to make a more specific flavor by adding (e.g.) garam masala, paprika, chili powder, etc. On my first use, I filled the pie shell pretty full, and it took 40-45 minutes to reach pie-brown. I was very fond of pot pie in the days before I adopted a vegetarian diet; I’ve not often found a good vegetable pot-pie in a restaurant or in a grocery store. This one satisfies my craving. My wife commented that it brought back childhood memories (g); for me it was perhaps more starving-student-day memories. My terrier begged for seconds, so the lack of meat was obviously not an issue! I think it can be served to meat-eaters without apology.
Awesome flavour in the filling and I added 1tbsp extra of cornstarch and baked mine in a cast iron skillet and used gluten-free crust. Great!
I too make extra veggies and freeze them. With prepared veggies quick week night meal and so delicious. Great fall/winter recipe
This recipe calls for way too many ingredients...it was impossible to fit it all in one pie.

Very happy with this recipe, easy to make, kids ate it, and the husband didn't complain about missing the meat. Ended up with enough for two pot pies, so had dinner and saved the rest for a future dinner.
We made it with a cornbread crust and it was "over the top"

This was very good. I used what veggies I had on hand (red onion, garlic, carrots, broccoli, cauliflower, yellow zucchini, and potatoes). I used 2 cups veggie broth and 3 Tbls. cornstarch and the sauce thickened up perfectly. If you plan to make a double pie crust don't bake the bottom first because you won't be able to seal and flute the top crust to the bottom.
I followed the recipe closly, but didn't like the result. There was very little flavor.
Delicious! It was a bit messy to serve, but tasted great!
Would be much better with chicken.

Wonderful! I added one extra Tbsp of corn starch to thicken, some extra garlic salt and soy sauce for flavor. The bottom of the pie crust was soggy, I would recommend the suggestion of another reviewer, to bake the crust for a bit before adding the filling. This made sufficient filling for two 9" pie crusts!

So delicious! I omitted the mushrooms and added 1 cup frozen peas and 1 cup frozen corn. I used fresh veggies for everything else-- and a frozen gluten free crust. Also followed previous recommendations and used a total of 5 tablespoons of cornstarch. So filling, fresh, and comforting--without any dead animals inside! Hooray! Highly recommend this recipe.
Loved this! Kids gobbled it up as well. Didn't have cornstarch so just sprinkled ~ 1/4 C over veggie mixture. Made enough filling for 2 pies IMO. Next time will make and freeze one
